bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to the Chief of the Forestry Department, August 28, 1940

div1.p: Hench requests help in assessing the age of framboyant trees.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to the Chief of the Forestry Department, August 28, 1940
div1.opener:
August 28, 1940
Chief of the Forestry Department
Washington, D. C.
Dear Sir:
div1.p:
I have been doing some medical historical researches on
the conquest of yellow fever, in preparation for an address and for certain
papers thereon. In this connection, I have visited some of the survivors
of the yellow fever experiments done by Major Walter Reed and his colleagues
in Havana in 1900, and have also visited or corresponded with General Kean
in Washington and General Truby in California. On my recent visit to Havana,
I found that the Cuban government had made rather elaborate plans for the
erection of a governmental memorial on the supposed site of Camp Lazear.
However, I found that they had chosen the wrong site and with the help of
Mr. Moran, one of the survivors of the yellow fever experiment, I was able
to rediscover the true site of the camp. By request, I presented my data
informally to their Excellencies, Dr. Ramos, Secretary of Defense, and Dr.
Moya, Secretary of Sanitation, They have asked me to submit this data in a
more formal documentary fashion so that they may correct their historical
error. Part of my evidence depends on determining the approximate age of
a framboyant tree on the site which they have erroneously memorialized,
and of another larger framboyant tree at the place where I believe the true
Camp Lazear was. I have obtained a photograph of both of these trees, but
was unable to find in Havana any tree expert from whom I might obtain the
approximate age of these trees. I understand that a framboyant tree is a
poinciana tree. Would it be possible for me to submit these photographs
to someone in your department for at least an informal expression of opinion
as to their probable age? In each photograph (and the photographs are good
ones, close up to the tree) there is either a human figure or some other
object from which one can estimate the approximate height of the tree. I would
certainly appreciate whatever help you can give me in this matter.
div1.closer: Very sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
